title: Dynamics of the decay eta->3pi0
summary:
The parameter $ \alpha = -0.005 \pm 0.007 (stat) \pm 0.004 (syst)$ describing
the density of events within the $ \eta \to 3\pi^0 $ Dalitz plot has been
measured using data from Brookhaven experiment E852. The result is compared to
previous values and theoretical predictions.

summary_detail.value:
The parameter $ \alpha = -0.005 \pm 0.007 (stat) \pm 0.004 (syst)$ describing
the density of events within the $ \eta \to 3\pi^0 $ Dalitz plot has been
measured using data from Brookhaven experiment E852. The result is compared to
previous values and theoretical predictions.

Abstract
The parameter α = −0.005 ± 0.007 (stat) ± 0.004 (syst) describing the density

Preprint submitted to Elsevier Preprint

15 November 2018

 of events within the η → 3π 0 Dalitz plot has been measured using data from
Brookhaven experiment E852. The result is compared to previous values and theoretical predictions.

1

Introduction

Chiral perturbation theory offers a consistent description of low energy QCD
particularly applicable to meson decays. An outstanding difficulty is the large
discrepancy between the predicted and observed rate of the η → 3π decay (1). We report here a measurement of the transition matrix element
| M(η → 3π 0 ) |2 . The density of events on the Dalitz plot has been predicted to
be uniform by Gasser and Leutwyler (1) and by Di Vecchia (2). More recently
a calculation of Kambor, Wiesendanger and Wyler (3) found a density which
decreases as the distance from the center of the plot increases.
The Dalitz plot density is specified by a single parameter, conventionally denoted as α. Kambor et al. show that both α and the rate Γ(η → 3π) are
sensitive to a parameter of the theory ( c in their notation ). The dependence
of α and Γ on c is such that a more negative value of α reduces the value of Γ
thereby increasing the disagreement with experiment. Two values of α are determined by the authors of (3), -0.014 and -0.007, the latter containing higher
order corrections and leading to a prediction for Γ(η → 3π) more consistent
with experiment.
To second order in the center of mass pion energy (4) - (7) the Dalitz plot
density for the decay η → 3π 0 is parameterized as
| M|2 ∝ 1 + 2αz

where Ei is the energy of the i'th pion in the η rest frame, ρ is the distance
from the center of the Dalitz plot and ρmax the largest kinematically allowable
value of ρ.
A uniformly populated Dalitz plot, (as predicted by (1) and (2)) gives α = 0. α
has been measured previously by Baglin et al. (5) , Alde et al. (6) , and Abele et
al. (7). Recent results are shown in figure 1 along with the result of this work.
Reference (7) finds a value significantly different from zero and in probable
disagreement (2σ) with theoretical expectations. The results reported in (5)
and (6) are consistent with both zero and the non-zero expectation of (3).

Fig. 1. Previous measurements of α and the result of this work with a comparison
to recent theoretical predictions. Not shown is the result of reference (5).

In this work we report on a determination of α from the decay η → 3π 0 where
the η was produced by 18.3 GeV/c negative pions incident on liquid hydrogen. The data were collected in 1995 by the Brookhaven National Laboratory
E852 collaboration. The apparatus has been described previously (8),(9) and
consisted of a large, segmented lead glass calorimeter (LGD), charged particle
tracking, veto and trigger systems capable of determining the charged particle
multiplicity and the total energy deposited in the lead glass.
3

 The data used for this analysis were collected with the "all-neutral" trigger
which required no charged particles, an energy deposition greater than 12 GeV
in the lead glass and no photons in the downstream photon veto.
η → 3π 0 decays were selected by requiring exactly 6 reconstructed clusters in
the LGD and a visible total energy greater than 16.5 GeV. All combinations of
assignments to the hypothesis 3π 0 were tested and if the best χ2 corresponded
to a confidence level greater than 1% the event was considered a candidate.
A preliminary fit using only the π 0 mass constraint was performed to allow
evaluation of the 3π 0 effective mass. Figure 2 shows the resulting distribution.
Events with a mass less than 0.65 GeV/c2 (corresponding to 3σ from the η
mass) were subjected to a full kinematic fit with the hypothesis π − p → ηn;
η → 3π 0 . A confidence level (CL) cut selected decays for the final analysis.
It also was required that no photon have an energy less than 0.25 GeV and
that the minimum separation between photons be larger than 9 cm. The effect
and purpose of these requirements is discussed below. The final resulting data
set contained 87,500 events.
To determine α, eq. 1 is fitted to the observed distribution of z corrected
for acceptance and phase space dependence. The acceptance correction was
based on Monte-Carlo simulation, taking into account the apertures of the
apparatus and a large sample of GEANT generated electromagnetic showers.
The requirements on the minimum photon energy and the minimum allowable photon separation mentioned above removed any uncertainties in the
Monte-Carlo simulation associated with the transverse development of electromagnetic showers and the behavior of low energy photons. The separation
requirement also selected events where the nearest two electromagnetic showers were well resolved. The phase space dependence of z was removed by dividing the observed distribution by the distribution due to a uniformly populated
Dalitz plot.
The distribution resulting from removing the phase space dependence and
correcting for the acceptance is proportional to M 2 and is shown in figure 3
along with the result of the fit to eq. 1. The distribution has been numerically
scaled to give a proportionality constant of one. Our result is α = −0.0047 ±
0.0074, where the error is statistical only.
Systematic effects have been considered and the important contributors identified. Since α is a static property of the η a measurement of α cannot depend
on any data selection requirement, for example, momentum-transfer, separation of photons in the detector, photon energy detection thresholds, confidence
level of fits, etc. It was observed that our measured α remained constant as a
function of the Confidence Level (CL) cut, down to about CL = 30%, below
which α began to fall slightly. This is consistent with an increasing contribu4

tion from reconstructed events with one or more wrong-assignments of a γ to
a π 0 . It was required the an event have a confidence level greater than 30% for
this analysis. Studies of the variation of α with the value chosen for the CL
cut yielded an estimate of ±0.003 for the systematic contribution associated
with this cut.
The analysis further required that no two photons have reconstructed impact
positions closer than 9 cm, a distance denoted by ∆r. Variation of the value of
∆r used in the analysis between 8.5 and 11 cm yielded our estimate of ±0.002
for the contribution to the systematic error due to this effect.
The effect of requiring the lowest energy photon to have an energy larger
than 0.25 GeV was investigated by removing this requirement (increasing the
data set by 1,140 events) and by replacing it with a requirement of 0.5 GeV
(decreasing the data set by 15,230 events). A contribution of ±0.001 to the
systematic error was found.

Fig. 3. Solid circles: z-distribution of η → 3π 0 events on the Dalitz plot. The solid
line is the result of a fit corresponding to eqn. 1. Open squares: the experimental

For 20% of the events in the data sample it was possible to choose more
than one assignment of photons to pions. The analysis presented here chose
the assignment with the best confidence level. The effect of this choice was
studied by choosing the second best assignment (when possible) and by using
all assignments with an appropriate weight to calculate α. No statistically
significant differences were observed.
Finally, the data set was divided into two statistically independent halves by
experimental run numbers and, separately, by range of momentum transfers.
In both cases, the values determined for α were not statistically significantly
different leading us to conclude these selections do not contribute to our systematic error. All effects considered combine to give our final estimate of
±0.004 for the systematic error.

6

 2

Conclusion

We have measured the α parameter of the transition matrix element M(η →
3π 0 ) to be α = −0.005 ± 0.007 (stat) ± 0.004 (syst). Our result differs from
one of the previous measurements (7) by slightly more than 2σ but is consistent with several other (6), (5) measurements. When compared to theoretical
expectations, the value of zero favored by Di Vecchia, Gasser and Leutwyler
(1) , (2),cannot be ruled out. The result reported here is consistent with the
two values (-0.007 and -0.014) reported by Kambor, Wiesendanger and Wyler
(3).
